raw_text:
Campbell to extend sprint career
 
 Darren Campbell has set his sights on running quicker than ever after deciding not to retire from sprinting.
 
 Campbell, who won Olympic 4x100m relay gold, had been unsure about his future. But he told Five Live's Sportsweek: "I had to get back into training before I could decide because if I didn't have the same hunger I'd have to walk away. "I've started back and I'm thoroughly enjoying it. I'm looking forward to it. I've got to run under 10 seconds (for 100m) and under 20 seconds (for 200m)." Campbell was part of the British quartet who shocked the Americans to win relay gold in Athens in August.
 
 The Newport-based athlete and team-mates Jason Gardener, Marlon Devonish and Mark Lewis-Francis were rewarded with MBEs in the New Year Honours List. Campbell's relay triumph made up for his disappointing displays in the individual 100m and 200m events in Athens, when he failed to reach the finals. The 31-year-old, who won Olympic 200m silver in Sydney in 2000, said during the Games that a hamstring injury had stopped him from running at his best.
 
 He was criticised at the time by former Olympic champion Michael Johnson, who cast doubt on Campbell's injury claims. "To go to Athens and finally get the gold I've been trying to get for 24 years was a big relief," said Campbell. "It was a chance for me to prove that if I'd been fit I would have been challenging for the (individual) medals. "Every season I go and challenge for the medals so why would last season have been any different? "It's just unfortunate that I picked up that injury just before the Olympics." Campbell set his 100m personal best of 10.04secs when he won the European title in Budapest in 1998. And he ran 20.13secs in the quarter-finals of the 200m in Sydney on the way to Olympic silver.
llama3.2:1b: Darren Campbell, who won gold in the 4x100m relay at the Olympics, has decided not to retire from sprinting after a season of training and is targeting a new personal best in the 100m dash. He had struggled with injury issues in individual events but achieved a silver medal in the 200m relay, which he credits for giving him renewed motivation to compete again.
llama3.2:3b: Darren Campbell has decided not to retire from sprinting and is aiming to run quicker than ever, setting targets for 100m (under 10 seconds) and 200m (under 20 seconds). He won Olympic relay gold in Athens but failed to reach individual finals due to a hamstring injury.
gemma2:2b: Darren Campbell will continue his sprinting career, aiming to run under 10 seconds for 100m and under 20 seconds for 200m. He has returned to training after a period of uncertainty and feels energized about pursuing these goals.  Campbell won Olympic relay gold with Great Britain in Athens and was awarded an MBE for his team's achievement. Despite not reaching the finals in individual events, he acknowledges a hamstring injury hindered his performance. Campbell is motivated to push for medals in future seasons.
qwen2.5:0.5b:
Darren Campbell, a sprinter who won individual and relay gold medals at the 2004 Athens Games, has decided not to retire from training. He is aiming to improve his time for the 100m and 200m events and has started running faster again after being unable to do so in Athens.

Campbell's previous performances were disappointing:
- Olympic 4x100m relay gold (not retired)
- Individual 100m silver (no longer retired but not as good)
- 200m silver at the Athens Games

He has been praised for his efforts in the individual events, saying he would have continued to compete if possible. However, recent injuries have hindered his progress and he must improve significantly to continue training.

Campbell's goal is to improve his personal best times for both events and increase his competitive performance going forward. He attributes his success at Athens to the chance to prove himself as a strong competitor.
qwen2.5:1.5b: Darren Campbell, who won Olympic gold in the 4x100m relay and was part of a British team that upset the Americans in the same event at Athens, has decided not to retire from sprinting after deciding he hasn't "had the same hunger" since stopping training, despite his desire to run faster than ever. Campbell aims to reach sub-10 seconds for the 100m and under-20 seconds for the 200m and is part of a team that received MBEs in the New Year Honours List.
qwen2.5:3b: Darren Campbell, who won Olympic 4x100m relay gold, has decided not to retire from sprinting after deciding his hunger and training were key factors before making a decision. He aims to run under 10 seconds for 100m and under 20 seconds for 200m. Campbell was part of the British team that shocked Americans in Athens, winning relay gold but missed individual finals due to injury claims that were later criticized by former Olympic champion Michael Johnson. Despite this criticism, Campbell believes he could have won medals if fit. He set his personal best of 10.04secs for 100m at the European title in 1998 and ran 20.13secs in Sydney's quarter-finals on route to Olympic silver.
